raw_text:
EU fraud clampdown urged
 
 EU member states are failing to report fraud and irregularities in EU funds on a consistent basis, the UK's public spending watchdog has said.
 
 The National Audit Office said although the latest figures showed reported fraud was falling, the EU still had no common definition of fraud. It also expressed concern that, for the 10th year, the European Court of Auditors had qualified the EU accounts. The NAO urged the government to push for improvements in reporting fraud. It said member states needed to be more accountable on how money was spent. The report said: "Member states still do not report fraud and other irregularities to the European Anti-Fraud Office on a consistent basis.
 
 "As the court has now qualified its opinion on the Community accounts for a decade, it is essential for all the authorities involved to contribute to the strengthening of the audit of EU revenue and expenditure and improving accountability for the financial management and use of EU resources." It said there were 922 cases of reported fraud or irregularities in EU funds in the UK in 2003, worth £38.5m (52m euros), up from 831 cases worth £35.7m in 2002. At the same time, reported fraud throughout the EU dropped from 10,276 cases worth £808m to 8,177 cases worth £644m. Edward Leigh, chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, said Britain had to set an example when it assumed the EU presidency.
 
 "Any fraud in other member states is potentially fraud against the UK taxpayer, given that we are the second largest net contributor to the Community," he said. "Departments responsible for administering EU funds need to make sure that they're doing everything possible to weed out improper spending. "The government must take the opportunity afforded by the UK presidency of the EU to press the Commission and other member states to take an equally robust stance against fraud and irregularity, and raise overall standards of financial management." A spokesman for the European Anti-Fraud Office said the organisation agreed with the NAO's assessment of fraud reporting. "The quality of reporting does differ from member state to member state, and there is room for improvement," spokesman Jorg Wojahn said. He added that there is generally good co-operation with member states and the anti-fraud office on specific cases of fraud, with the statistics studied by NAO providing a "good overview for planning strategic ways of detecting fraud".
llama3.2:1b: EU member states are failing to report fraud and irregularities in EU funds on a consistent basis, according to the UK's public spending watchdog.
Despite showing improvement, reported fraud is still falling despite the European Court of Auditors qualifying its opinion on the Community accounts for the 10th year.
The National Audit Office has urged governments to push for improvements in reporting fraud.
There were 922 cases of reported fraud or irregularities in EU funds in the UK in 2003 and 8,177 cases worth £644m in the same period.
Britain has been given an opportunity as the second largest net contributor to the European Union, but it must take a more robust stance against fraud and improve its financial management.
llama3.2:3b: EU member states are not consistently reporting fraud and irregularities in EU funds, despite a decline in reported fraud.
The UK's public spending watchdog urges the government to push for improvements in reporting fraud and accountability for financial management.
Reported fraud has dropped from 10,276 cases worth £808m to 8,177 cases worth £644m over two years, with the EU having no common definition of fraud.
gemma2:2b: EU member states are not consistently reporting fraud and irregularities related to EU funds.
Despite falling reported fraud numbers, there is no common definition of fraud in the EU, and the European Court of Auditors has qualified the EU accounts for ten years running.
The National Audit Office recommends pushing for better reporting, increased accountability, and a stronger audit of EU financial management.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The UK needs to improve reporting fraud in EU funds, which has led to 831 reported cases worth £35.7m since 2002.
Members must be accountable on how money is spent.
The European Anti-Fraud Office agrees with the NAO's assessment and recommends improvements in reporting.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The UK's Public Accounts Office has found EU countries are failing to consistently report fraudulent activities using European funds.
The European Court of Auditors has qualified accounts for 10 years in a row due to inconsistent reporting, and the NAO urged member states to improve their accountability on spending.
There were 922 reported cases of fraud or irregularities in UK EU funds in 2003 worth £38.5m compared to 831 worth £35.7m in 2002, but overall fraud dropped across the EU.
Edward Leigh called for Britain to set an example by leading on fighting fraud due to its second-largest net contribution as a member of the European Union.
The spokesman for the European Anti-Fraud Office agreed with NAO's assessment and emphasized room for improvement in quality of reporting while noting good co-operation on specific cases.
qwen2.5:3b: EU member states are failing to consistently report fraud and irregularities in EU funds, according to the UK's public spending watchdog.
While reported fraud is decreasing, there remains no common definition of fraud within the EU, leading to repeated criticisms from the European Court of Auditors.
The NAO urged for improvements in reporting.
In 2003, 922 cases worth £38.5m were reported in the UK; this number increased by one case but dropped to £644m across the EU.
Edward Leigh emphasized that fraud anywhere could affect UK taxpayers due to Britain's status as a major net contributor.
The government should use its presidency to push for stricter standards against fraud and irregularity, with the European Anti-Fraud Office supporting these measures.
opencoder:1.5b: The EU has urged government support for improving reporting procedures to address any fraudulent transactions that may occur within the EU.
It expressed concerns about how member states would be held accountable when it comes to their financial use in the EU.
The National Audit Office, a member of the public, stressed that while reports show consistent fraud, there is still no clear definition for what constitutes fraud.
Some member states report suspicious transactions on a regular basis, while others report more extreme fraudulent activities.
However, the public accounts committee from 2003 highlighted the need to contribute to audit processes and raise standards of financial management, thereby ensuring accountability.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The UK's public spending watchdog calls for changes due to EU member states failing to report fraud inconsistently.
The National Accountant Office (NAAO) notes that while reported fraud has been rising, the EU lacks a unified definition of fraud and has faced court opinions questioning its findings.
In 2003, the UK had fewer cases of reported fraud than the EU, rising from 831 to 922 cases in £35.7m (52m euros).
EU cases dropped from 10,276 to 8,177 cases worth £644m.
Member states are expected to act like the UK when acting at their EU presidency.
The government must improve reporting standards equally across member states.
The EU Anti-Fraud Office agrees with NAO's assessment of varied levels of fraud reporting and highlights good cooperation among member states and the anti-fraud office.
tinyllama:1.1b: The EU member states are failing to report fraud and irreguilarities in EU funds consistently, according to data published by the UK public spend watchdog.
The National Audit Office (NAO) urged the government to push for improvements in reporting fraud, as member states continue to do not report on a consistent basis.
The report also stated that 922 cases of reported fraud or irregularities were reported in the UK in 2003, worth £38.5m (€47.6m), up from 831 cases worth £35.7m in 2002.
The data showed that reported fraud throughout the EU dropped from 10,276 cases worth £808m to 8,177 cases worth £644m.

The NAO also highlighted that departments responsible for administrating EU funds need to make sure they are doing everything possible to weed out improper spendings, and raise overall standards of financial management in the EU.

The European Anti-Fraud Office (EAF), which is responsible for co-operating with member states on specific cases of fraud, noted that there is generally good cooperation and statistics studied by NAO provide a "good overview" for planning strategic ways of detecting fraud in the EU.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAE), the EU's independent audit authority, has expressed concerns about the level of reporting fraud and irregularities in EU funds.
According to the UK's public spending watchdog, the National Audit Office (NAO), a total of 922 cases of reported fraud or irregularities were reported in the UK during 2003, worth £38.5m.
This amount has increased from 831 cases worth £35.7m in 2002.
The NAO urges the government to push for improvements in reporting fraud by member states, as the European Court of Auditors has qualified their accounts for a decade.
The report also states that there were 922 cases of reported fraud or irregularities in EU funds in the UK in 2003 worth £38.5m, up from 831 cases worth £35.7m in 2002.
This has caused concern among EU member states who are still not reporting fraud and other irregularities to the European Anti-Fraud Office on a consistent basis.
phi:2.7b: The European Union (EU) has called for improved reporting of fraud and irregularities in EU funds among member states.
The UK's public spending watchdog found that although reported fraud is falling, there is still no common definition of fraud in the EU.
Additionally, the 10th year in a row has seen the European Court of Auditors qualify the EU accounts due to lack of consistency in reporting.
The National Audit Office (NAO) urges the government to push for better reporting and accountability from member states on how money is spent.
They suggest improving the audit of EU revenue and expenditure and setting an example as the UK assumes the EU presidency.
The NAO report indicates that there has been a decrease in reported fraud throughout the EU, but Britain still needs to take steps to prevent fraud in other countries.

Edward Leigh, chairman of the public accounts committee, emphasizes the importance of addressing fraudulent activity in EU funds, which can potentially affect British taxpayers as one of the largest net contributors to the EU.

The NAO reports a 922 cases of reported fraud or irregularities in EU funds worth £38.5 million in the UK in 2003, while the overall reported fraud throughout the EU fell from 10,276 cases worth £808m in 2002 to 8,177 cases worth £644m.

The spokesperson for the European Anti-Fraud Office agrees with the NAO's assessment and highlights the need for better reporting quality and co-operation between member states to detect fraud more effectively.
orca-mini:3b: The UK public spending watchdog has urged the government to push for improvements in reporting fraud and accountability in how EU funds are spent.

It expressed concern that member states have not consistently reported fraud and irregularities in EU funds, and that 922 cases of fraud were reported in the UK worth £38.5m in 2003, up from 831 cases worth £35.7m in 2002.

The National Audit Office urged departments responsible for administering EU funds to make sure they are doing everything possible to weed out improper spending, and that the UK presidency of the EU can be used to raise overall standards of financial management.

Edward Leigh, chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, emphasized that any fraud in other member states could potentially be fraud against the UK taxpayer as it is the second largest net contributor to the Community.
